quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 5 Quiz 2
quiz.subtitle: 5.2: Alcohols Properties
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Hydrogen bonding, boiling points, and solubility

questions.question: Why do alcohols have significantly higher boiling points than alkanes of similar molar mass?
options: They can form intermolecular hydrogen bonds
They have stronger London dispersion forces
The $C-O$ bond is stronger than the $C-C$ bond
Alcohols are always found as solids at room temperature
questions.explanation: The highly electronegative oxygen atom creates a strong dipole. Hydrogen atoms attached to oxygen can form hydrogen bonds with lone pairs on neighboring oxygen atoms, requiring more energy to overcome.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the solubility of small-chain alcohols (like methanol and ethanol) in water?
questions.explanation: Small alcohols can form hydrogen bonds with water molecules, allowing them to mix in all proportions.

questions.question: What happens to the water solubility of alcohols as the length of the alkyl chain increases?
options: Solubility depends only on the number of oxygen atoms
questions.explanation: As the non-polar (hydrophobic) hydrocarbon chain grows, it overrides the polar effect of the $-OH$ group, making the molecule less compatible with water.

questions.question: Comparing $1$-propanol and propane, which statement is true?
options: $1$-propanol is a liquid at room temperature while propane is a gas
Propane has a higher boiling point because it is non-polar
Both have identical boiling points due to similar mass
questions.explanation: Propane ($BP \approx -42^{\circ}C$) lacks hydrogen bonding, whereas $1$-propanol ($BP \approx 97^{\circ}C$) is held together by strong intermolecular forces.

questions.question: Among isomeric alcohols, how does branching affect the boiling point?
options: Branching has no effect on boiling point
Branching only affects the melting point
questions.explanation: Similar to alkanes, branching reduces the surface area available for London dispersion forces, leading to a lower boiling point for branched isomers compared to straight chains.

questions.question: Which alcohol would you expect to have the highest boiling point?
questions.explanation: Ethane-$1,2$-diol has two $-OH$ groups, allowing for more extensive hydrogen bonding per molecule than ethanol or methanol.

questions.question: The $-OH$ group in alcohols is described as being:
questions.explanation: The hydroxyl group is hydrophilic because it can participate in hydrogen bonding with water.

questions.question: What is the primary intermolecular force between molecules of ethanol?
questions.explanation: While ethanol has London forces and dipole-dipole interactions, hydrogen bonding is the dominant force determining its physical properties.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the density of most simple alcohols?
options: They are generally less dense than water
They are significantly denser than water
They have the same density as liquid mercury
They are only dense in the gas phase
questions.explanation: Most liquid alcohols have densities between $0.78$ and $0.85$ g/mL, making them lighter than water ($1.00$ g/mL).

questions.question: Why does $1$-butanol have a higher boiling point than diethyl ether, despite having the same molecular formula ($C_{4}H_{10}O$)?
options: $1$-butanol can form hydrogen bonds; diethyl ether cannot
Diethyl ether is a much larger molecule
The ether oxygen is not electronegative
questions.explanation: Isomeric ethers do not have a hydrogen atom bonded directly to oxygen, so they cannot form intermolecular hydrogen bonds with themselves, resulting in lower boiling points.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a clear understanding of how the hydroxyl group influences physical properties.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. You grasp the trends in boiling points and solubility well.
scoreMessages.50: Keep it up. Remember to compare the effects of chain length vs. hydrogen bonding.
scoreMessages.0: Review the concept of hydrogen bonding and its requirements.
